articles.headline: Wal-Mart Asks Supreme Court to Hear Bias Suit
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court could review the largest employment discrimination lawsuit in American history.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court could review the largest employment discrimination lawsuit in American history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to review the largest employment discrimination lawsuit in American history, involving more than a million female workers, current and former, at Wal-Mart and Sam’s Club stores.

articles.headline: Learning Curves on the Career Path
articles.snippet: Whether they are concerned about job security or climbing the career ladder, people often conclude that if there’s any solution, it’s more education.
articles.abstract: Whether they are concerned about job security or climbing the career ladder, people often conclude that if there’s any solution, it’s more education.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Every day we know less and less about more and more,” said Ray Caprio, vice president for continuing education at Rutgers University.

articles.headline: The Humanities for Love, Not Money
articles.snippet: Continuing education programs across the country are finding students increasingly focused on the arts and humanities, whether for new careers or to re-explore great authors.
articles.abstract: Continuing education programs across the country are finding students increasingly focused on the arts and humanities, whether for new careers or to re-explore great authors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the renowned educators Mortimer J. Adler and Robert Maynard Hutchins first decided to expand their Great Books course beyond the University of Chicago’s walls, they recruited some of Chicago’s most prominent businessmen. In what was called the Fat Men’s Great Books Course, the executives and their wives started meeting every other Friday evening in the fall of 1943 to discuss Plato, Shakespeare and Goethe.

articles.headline: New Kindle Leaves Rivals Farther Back
articles.snippet: Amazon introduces an e-book reader that everyone (except Amazon) calls the Kindle 3. It’s a response to the iPad, with improved E Ink screen technology.
articles.abstract: Amazon introduces an e-book reader that everyone (except Amazon) calls the Kindle 3. It’s a response to the iPad, with improved E Ink screen technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Too bad there’s not a reality TV show called “America’s Most Freaked-Out Tech-Company Meetings,” where you watch classic panicked board meetings. For example, when the Apple employee left an iPhone 4 prototype in a bar. Or when Intel learned that its Pentium chip contained a math error. Or when Microsoft was caught bribing bloggers with $2,500 laptops to promote Windows Vista.

articles.headline: Shaping Tea Party Passion Into Campaign Force
articles.snippet: A Washington group is building the Tea Party movement, house by house and yard sign by yard sign.
articles.abstract: A Washington group is building the Tea Party movement, house by house and yard sign by yard sign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On a Saturday in August when most of the political class has escaped this city’s swelter, 50 Tea Party leaders have flown in from across the country to jam into a conference room in an office building on Pennsylvania Avenue, apparently unconcerned that the fancy address does not guarantee air-conditioning on weekends. They have come to learn how to take over the country, voter by voter.

articles.headline: A High-Tech Titan Plagued by Potholes
articles.snippet: India, which is flooded with software engineers, lacks skilled professionals interested in overhauling the nation’s decaying highways, power plants and railroads.
articles.abstract: India, which is flooded with software engineers, lacks skilled professionals interested in overhauling the nation’s decaying highways, power plants and railroads.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUNE, India  Call it India’s engineering paradox.

articles.headline: Karzai Aide in Corruption Inquiry Is Tied to C.I.A.
articles.snippet: Officials say an aide to the president of Afghanistan being investigated for corruption is being paid by the C.I.A.
articles.abstract: Officials say an aide to the president of Afghanistan being investigated for corruption is being paid by the C.I.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The aide to President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan at the center of a politically sensitive corruption investigation is being paid by the Central Intelligence Agency, according to Afghan and American officials.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Despite Reform, Banks Have Room for Risky Deals
articles.snippet: Even with regulation, some federally insured banks say they will continue to make bets using their own money on behalf of clients.
articles.abstract: Even with regulation, some federally insured banks say they will continue to make bets using their own money on behalf of clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Congress passed a new financial regulation bill last month, it sought to prevent federally insured banks from making speculative bets using their own money. But that will not stop banks from making bets that some critics deem risky, even as the rules go into effect over the next few years.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Fraud Ruling Is Reshaping Federal Cases
articles.snippet: The dismissal of a fraud prosecution against two former Westar Energy executives illustrates the new challenges federal prosecutors face in trying “honest services” cases.
articles.abstract: The dismissal of a fraud prosecution against two former Westar Energy executives illustrates the new challenges federal prosecutors face in trying “honest services” cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon, a federal judge swore in Barry R. Grissom as the United States attorney in Kansas.

articles.headline: Bernanke to Offer Outlook as Fed Weighs Bolder Steps
articles.snippet: Facing a a worrying low inflation rate and persistently high unemployment, Ben S. Bernanke may signal the Federal Reserve’s course in a speech Friday.
articles.abstract: Facing a a worrying low inflation rate and persistently high unemployment, Ben S. Bernanke may signal the Federal Reserve’s course in a speech Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With fresh signs that the housing market is weakening, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Friday will offer his outlook on the economy, explain the Fed’s recent modest move to halt the slide and possibly outline other actions.

articles.headline: Exiled Tycoon Returns to Britain to Face Charges
articles.snippet: Asil Nadir, who fled Britain in 1993 following the collapse of his business empire, returned to face fraud charges.
articles.abstract: Asil Nadir, who fled Britain in 1993 following the collapse of his business empire, returned to face fraud charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Asil Nadir, the disgraced Turkish-Cypriot businessman whose Levantine panache and deal-making zeal rattled Britain’s stodgy corporate establishment in the 1980s, returned here Thursday to face charges that he embezzled £30 million while running the London-based conglomerate Polly Peck International.
